div.span: Showers and thunderstorms likely. Cloudy, with a high near 58. West southwest wind 5 to 15 mph, with gusts as high as 30 mph. Chance of precipitation is 70%. New precipitation amounts between a tenth and quarter of an inch, except higher amounts possible in thunderstorms.

Rain. Low around 44. Breezy, with a northwest wind 15 to 20 mph, with gusts as high as 30 mph. Chance of precipitation is 90%. New precipitation amounts between a quarter and half of an inch possible.

Rain likely before 7am, then a chance of showers, mainly between 7am and 4pm. Cloudy, with a high near 51. Breezy, with a north northwest wind 15 to 20 mph, with gusts as high as 35 mph. Chance of precipitation is 60%. New precipitation amounts of less than a tenth of an inch possible.

span.strong: Inspiring Dreams Â * Â Empowering Minds Â * Â Strengthening Community

h3.a: MCUSD#1 Releases Remote Learning Calendar for April

div.p: We are continuingÂ to organize and develop structures for Remote Learning, and with that, we developed a calendar to help better understand and visualizeÂ
important dates for the next month.Â Please understand this calendar was developed with information available on April 1.

a.aria-label: Read more about MCUSD#1 Releases Remote Learning Calendar for April

p.b: Good morning,

As the State Superintendent indicated over the weekend, all Illinois schools will begin Remote Learning Days beginning today, Tuesday, 3/31.Â Our primary focus remains the same- to keep children emotionally safe, physically safe, fed, and engaged in learning. Thank you for all of the support you have provided to our staff during this time!Â We ask that you please continue to support us in this. With that being said, at this time, we are taking the following steps. Â
Meals/Packet Pick-up
At this time, we will continue to use Monday for meal delivery and packet pick-up.
ADJUSTED TIMES:
MEALS ON WHEELS: LEAVING DISTRICT AT 12:45, PLEASE BE READY TO MEET BUSSES.
GRAB-N-GO: 1-2PM AT MECC
PACKET PICK-UP AT ALL BUILDINGS 1-2PM
Modified CalendarÂ
We are in the final stages of sending out an updated calendar for the month of April.Â We will send it out via Teacherease, post it on FB, and also the district homepage.Â Â

meta.b: This Thursday, April 2nd, students WILL NOT have assignments, and teachers WILL NOT be available to help students. Teacher will use the day for Remote Learning Planning.Â Remote Learning will resume Friday.

p.b: Grading
Student tasks will now be graded.Â We are following guidance issued by ISBE, and more specific information will be released as soon as possible.Â Students need to complete all assigned tasks.Â
Digital Learning DeliveryÂ Â

MCUSD#1 staff will be implementing a variety of strategies to deliver the lessons electronically to your student.Â We have been using Google Classroom for the past three years and this program is effective in delivering content. Other apps (Zoom, GotoMeeting, BlueJeans) that contain a video conferencing feature may be used for the purpose of teaching and learning and delivery of instruction.Â We have posted a district Privacy Disclosure in the Remote Learning tab on each schoolâs homepage. If you do not agree with having your child in the video, then contact your teacher or building Principal.Â In some cases, the solution may be as simple as changing the settings, or having your child receive packets.
Special Needs

Special Education Teachers will continue to collaborate with staff to implement IEPs.Â Students with IEP meetings coming up will be contacted by the Special Ed Department. Meetings may be conducted in an alternative format, due to Covid-19.Â Â
MTSS/ELL

Interventionists and ELL teachers will continue to work in collaboration with classroom teachers and provide support as necessary; this may mean contacting students, or providing lesson development strategies and support.Â At this time interventionists will continue to provide Tier 3 support.Â Â
Graduation requirements
High school Graduation requirements are currently being discussed at ISBE and the Governorâs Office.Â We will provide information as it is released to Illinois schools.

a.aria-label: Read more about Remote Learning Guidance

p.b: Recently, our district technology department sent a 3 question survey on Teacherease.Â We ask that you please take a moment to complete the survey at your earliest convenience. Thank you and have a great day.

meta.b: Recientemente, nuestro departamento de tecnologÃ­a del distrito enviÃ³ una encuesta de 3 preguntas sobre Teacherease. Le pedimos que se tome un momento para completar la encuesta lo antes posible. Gracias y que tengas un buen dÃ­a.

h3.a: Some Things You Need to Know About the Census

p.b: HOW MOMENCE BENEFITS FROM THE CENSUS

Responding to the census helps communities get the funding they need and helps businesses make data-driven decisions that grow the economy.Â Census data impact our daily lives, informing important decisions about funding for services and infrastructure in our community, including healthcare, senior services, jobs, political representation, roads, schools, and businesses.Â More than $675 billion in federal funding flows back to states and local communities each year based on census data.
HOW THE 2020 CENSUS WILL CONTACT YOU

The first opportunity will be to respond online or by phone.Â A letter will be sent to all families with instructions to reply online or by phone.Â The online form and phone menu will be available in 13 languages, including English. There will be language guides available in 59 languages other than English.Â Some families may receive a letter and a paper response form. The initial letter will arrive between March 12 and 20 and a reminder letter will arrive between March 16
and 24.
Those who have not responded to the initial request will receive a reminder postcard between March 26 and April 3, then a reminder letter with a paper questionnaire between April 8 and 16.
Between April 20 and 27 a final reminder postcard will be sent before census workers begin to
follow up with non-responding households.

It is extremely important that every resident of Momence participate in the 2020 Census.Â Every person missed means dollars not available to repair streets, maintain sidewalks and upkeep the infrastructure of our community.
COMPUTER AND INTERNET ACCESS

Families who do not have computer or internet access can do so at Edward Chipman Public Library, 126 N. Locust St. in Momence. Starting April 1st, Wednesdays from 12- 6 PM and Thursdays from 4- 8 PM four workstations and our staff will be devoted to assisting you with Census 2020.
CONFIDENTIALITY IS GUARANTEED IN 2020 CENSUS

By law (Title 13 of the US Code) census responses cannot be used against you by any government agency or court in any way â not by the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), not by the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA), not by the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and not by US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE).Â The law requires the Census Bureau to keep your information confidential and use your responses only to create statistics.Â
Your response to the 2020 Census cannot affect your residency in the U.S.Â Â
Your responses to the 2020 Census are safe, secure, and protected by federal law.Â Your answers can
only be used to produce statistics. They cannot be used against you by any government agency or court in any wayânot by the FBI, not by the CIA, not by the DHS, and not by ICE.

a.aria-label: Read more about Some Things You Need to Know About the Census

h3.a: Congrats to all MCHS Student Drivers!

div.p: Congrats to ourÂ MCHS student drivers for doing the right thing while driving in and out of school zones.Â Special shout out to our families and driver's education teachers (Mr. Cherry,Â Mr. Ecker, and Mr. Rounds) for instilling these values in our student body.Â Â

a.aria-label: Read more about Congrats to all MCHS Student Drivers!

h3.a: Mr. LaVigne's class visited the Advocate Christ Hospital

div.p: Mr. LaVigne'sÂ Human Biology classes visited the Advocate Christ Hospital to observe open heartÂ surgery.Â Students observed the medical team repairing an aneurysm on the aorta.Â They were able to interact with the medical team and ask questions as they completedÂ the procedure.Â They were one of four school present along withÂ a remote connection with the Museum of Science and Industry in Chicago.Â Â

a.aria-label: Read more about Mr. LaVigne's class visited the Advocate Christ Hospital

h3.a: MJHS Students Rock at Math Competition!

div.h4: 6th Grade Takes 1st Place, 7th and 8th Graders Finish 2nd

div.p: MomenceÂ Jr. High recently held it's yearly Math Competition, and, as in years past, there was reason to celebrate.Â MJHSÂ students claimed the top spot in the 6th Grade A Division, squeaking past WatsekaÂ by 4 points, 494-490, while Bishop McNamara took the 3rd spot with 414 points respectively.Â The 7th and 8th Grade MJHSÂ squads both tookÂ 2nd place honors in the A Dvision.Â In the 7th Grade A Division, the same 3 schools finished in the top 3, but WatsekaÂ came out on top with 546 points, while MJHSÂ had 513 and Bishop Mac again took 3rd with 470 points.Â The 8th Grade Team from Bishop Mac finished 1st in their competition, with 549 points, while MJHSÂ grabbed 513 points and the Iroquois West Team scored 448 points to take 3rd.
The double AA Division results are included:
7th- Coal City 702, Columbia Central 562, Hickory Creek 559
Thanks to all participating schools for making this event, and thanks to all parents and staff for your hard work and encouraging our students to excel in mathematics.

a.aria-label: Read more about MJHS Students Rock at Math Competition!

h3.a: MJHS Student News Continues to Evolve

div.p: Have you subscribed to the MJHS Student News yet?Â If you haven't, you're missing out.Â Presented by MJHS students, this production continuesÂ to improve over the course of this school year.Â Subscribe today!
